Articles.Content:
I'd spent a couple hours making an animation using Shape Keys, only to learn KSP doesn't support Shape Keys.

I know animation by translation, rotation and scaling of entire objects is supported. What else can I do?

I'm trying to do an unwrapping/unrolling spiral - how could I get it without treating the spiral as dozens of objects and managing each of them across a lot of keyframes (whenever next segment begins unrolling and the angle of rotation of the whole changes)?

If you have split them into segments (like a centipede) what worked for my 12 panel comms (it is stored in a small cubby and when 'deployed' the 12 panels unfurl in a counter clockwise fashion, staggered apart from each other to avoid fouling, before sliding back their respective amount to create a smooth single dish) antenna might work for you.

I use 'constraint' in blender along with plain axes and correctly 'parenting' parts, fixed a set pivot point (which is easier for my example as its a collective simply rotation) and then set the keyframes for only a few points such as when they start, then the final rotation position then their final translation position. I did have to set these keyframes on each of the individual pieces of the part but I think that is unavoidable.

Obviously what you are trying to do is not quite as simple as all that. However I think (if using the segmented section approach) it could be achieved by using multiple constraints on each segment to get it to work, if you give the first segment a 'plain axis' at each end, say pivot A and pivot B, parent the segment to Pivot A, parent pivot A to the main body of whatever you are attaching it to and then parent pivot B to the segment. Each subsequent segment gets a pivot B so each child segment get 'parented' to the pivot B of the segment before.

I'm pretty sure (but can't test it on this machine) that if you setup each segment to the rotation you wanted it to be at when stowed and stored the keyframe, then put each segment at the rotation you would want it to be extended and recorded the keyframes there then blender would sort the rest out.

Amendment: I think I may have missed part of the original question, as to whether this could be done for a single part I am unsure (I would not know how to achieve it with a single spiralled mesh). Should you choose the multiple mesh route I hope that I may have been able to shed some light on a possible solution. I personally construct things in a mechanical fashion and try to think how a thing could be realised with current techniques.

Edited October 25, 2016 by steedcrugeon

You can use Armatures and Bones. Uses a bit more CPU to do the animation but saves the GPU usage when doing tons of small objects.

My Proton Launch Pad for example is just one Mesh for the whole inner part with all the moving parts.
@steedcrugeon: Hey, "proper parenting" really made the work easy. I've re-created the day's work in less than an hour, and three keyframes total.
@Sharpy glad it worked for you, be interested to see the finished result!
